posts.name: bharrison6
posts.cooked:
Our FIRST Robotics Competition team (3843) is encountering an intermittent error that halts our robot code mid-enablement, causing automatic disconnection. This issue occasionally surfaces during test drives. Our analysis of the log files hasn't revealed any obvious or fixable errors, and the root cause remains unclear. Notably, our roborio experiences increased CPU usage during these sessions.

The error message indicates that the startCompetition() method failed to handle an exception. The stack trace suggests the issue originates from the RobotBase.runRobot method in RobotBase.java, specifically around line 440, and eventually leads to an unhandled IllegalStateException related to stream processing.

While attempting to debug, we've noticed spikes in CPU usage, which may point toward resource-intensive operations or potential concurrency issues. If you have any insights or require additional details, feel free to share them.

link_counts.title: Reading Stacktraces — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: BillDunlap
posts.cooked: The log above appears to describe an error where the startCompetition() method (or methods called by it) failed to handle an exception. The error occurred in edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.RobotBase.runRobot(RobotBase.java:440). The question is whether the log you provided shows the full details of this exception, including a traceback, or if you only showed information below this message.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: This is most likely caused by calling Alert from a secondary thread. Alert is not thread-safe. If you’re using Akit, this can be caused by calling Akit logging functions from a secondary thread.

posts.name: bharrison6
posts.cooked: Nothing in this context that stands out.

posts.name: bharrison6
posts.cooked: That, as far as I am aware, we have not called alert anywhere in our code, though we are using it, YAGSL. Could it be that YAGSL is causing the problem?

the cleaned-up text: It seems that your YAGSL vendor depot is out of date. Have you tried updating it and seeing if that fixes the issue? (The most recent version seems to be 2025.7.2) I made minimal changes to ensure the text makes sense while preserving its original meaning. ``` It seems that your YAGSL vendor dep is out of date. Have you tried updating it and seeing if that fixes the HTML issue? (The most recent version seems to be 2025.7.2) ``` I removed the unnecessary `

posts.name: bharrison6
posts.cooked:
We updated it, but it didn't work as expected when trying to update using the "update all" option or by clicking the update button. This forced us to remove the existing library and reinstall it to get the updates. That's why our libraries are often out of date, as we update them roughly once a week.

Hopefully, this issue is related to that. Out of curiosity, could this problem be caused by something involving a CAN (Controller Area Network) issue? We are definitely not meeting the required specifications for our CAN stubs.

posts.name: Ben Malito
posts.cooked:
>
Okay, so I'm trying to help clean up this user's text. They want me to remove all HTML tags and unnecessary stuff while keeping the meaning intact. Let me look at the original text.

First, there are two paragraphs here. The first one starts with "I think if this were caused by a CAN issue..." and has several spans with class abbreviations. I need to get rid of those HTML tags. So, I'll replace each <span...> with just "CAN" since it's an abbreviation for Controller Area Network.

Also, in the first sentence, they mention seeing high CAN bus usage on the Driverstation. I should check if "Driverstation" needs capitalization. Since it's likely a proper noun referring to a specific system or interface, it probably should be capitalized.

The second part asks about loop overruns in the 20ms CommandScheduler loop. I need to make sure that term is clear. Maybe "loop" could be pluralized as "loops" for better grammar, but the original uses "loop", which is correct if it's singular.

Putting it all together, I'll combine both paragraphs into a single block without line breaks. I'll also ensure proper punctuation and grammar, like adding commas where necessary. For example, after "mid-practice/mid-match," I should add a period to complete the sentence properly.

Let me read through my cleaned version to make sure it flows naturally and retains all the important information without being too altered.
</ignore>

Final Answer:
I think if this were caused by a CAN issue, you would be able to see very high CAN bus usage on the Driverstation. If you still have the logs from when this issue was happening, you might try to search for any CAN-related messages within the log. Are you having issues with loop overruns? If your robot code overruns the 20ms CommandScheduler loop, that can cause your code to crash mid-practice/mid-match.

posts.name: bharrison6
posts.cooked: Just an update. We updated all of our code and never had another issue. Maybe something in the update fixed the code or maybe we still have an issue but haven't triggered it again. It was very infrequent. Thanks to all who helped!
